block.p: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

BARBARA CARROLL, Bemelmans Bar, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. This agelessly chic red-haired pianist and singer seems to know every important popular song ever written and to be able to perform from memory in any key. Her elegant, lyrical pianism is a compendium of 20th-century jazz styles, from Count Basie to Erroll Garner to Bill Evans and beyond. And her clipped, understated vocals, which verge on speech-song, approach lyrics from a wry but warmhearted point of view. Through July 22. Tuesday through Saturday nights, beginning at 9:30. From 5:30 to 8, Michael Devine. No cover for early show; cover for late show: $15. No minimum; $5 cover at the bar.
Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

BARBARA CARROLL, Bemelmans Bar, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. This agelessly chic red-haired pianist and singer seems to know every important popular song ever written and to be able to perform from memory in any key. Her elegant, lyrical pianism is a compendium of 20th-century jazz styles, from Count Basie to Erroll Garner to Bill Evans and beyond. And her clipped, understated vocals, which verge on speech-song, approach lyrics from a wry but warmhearted point of view. Through July 22. Tuesday through Saturday nights, beginning at 9:30. From 5:30 to 8, Michael Devine. No cover for early show; cover for late show: $15. No minimum; $5 cover at the bar.

* HOWARD FISHMAN QUARTET, Sardi's, 234 West 44th Street, (212) 221-8440. Powerful echoes of Stephane Grappelli and Bix Beiderbecke are among the influences rippling through the Howard Fishman Quartet's seamless swing. The group -- Mr. Fishman on guitar, banjo and vocals; Russell Farhang playing virtuosic Grappelli-style violin; Peter Ecklund on cornet; Andrew Hall on bass -- folds elements of vintage jazz, swing and early bluegrass into rhythmically animated, richly allusive jazz chamber music. Whether the music is Stephen Foster (a bubbly ''Old Folks at Home''), Gershwin (''Soon'') or Romberg (''When I Grow Too Old to Dream''), it is all translated into lilting, fine-tuned ensemble music that transcends time and idiom. Fridays at 10:30 p.m. No cover charge, but $15 minimum at tables.

* ''OUR SINATRA,'' Blue Angel Theater, 323 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. The rising young cabaret star Eric Comstock is the mastermind behind this utterly winning tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes, which focuses on what Mr. Comstock calls the hidden gems and orphan songs that Sinatra made popular. Joined by Christopher Gines, a creamy baritone who echoes Dick Haymes and Steve Lawrence in their prime, and Hilary Kole, a perky swinger, Mr. Comstock conducts a witty and knowledgeable survey of the Sinatra canon. Mr. Comstock concentrates on the mature Sinatra and Mr. Gines on the dreamy 1940's balladeer, with Ms. Kole bridging the gap. The memorable show proves that there are still young singers good enough to keep the tradition alive. Tonight, tomorrow, Monday and Thursday at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 and 7:30 p.m.; Wednesday at 2:30 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $50 and $55 (premium ringside seating, $75 and $80).

ARCI'S PLACE, 450 Park Avenue South, at 30th Street, (212) 532-4370. Monday nights at 8 in July, Jim Caruso, singer, and Billy Stritch, singer-pianist. Beginning Tuesday, Lillias White. Tuesdays through Thursdays at 9; Fridays and Saturdays at 8:30 and 11 p.m. Cover: $25; $15 minimum.
CLEOPATRA'S NEEDLE, 2485 Broadway, at 92nd Street, (212) 769-6969. Tonight at 9, 10:30 p.m. and midnight, Laurie Krauz, singer. No cover: $10 minimum at tables; $7 minimum at bar.

DANNY'S SKYLIGHT ROOM, 346 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 265-8133. Tonight from 9 to 1 in the piano bar, Jerry Scott. Tomorrow night from 5 to 9 in the piano bar, Chuck Musone; at 7, Michele Leigh Comedy hour; from 9 to 1 in the piano bar, Mr. Scott. Sunday night from 7 to 11, Sol Yaged and friends. Monday night from 8 to midnight, Chris Barrett. Cover: free to $15; $10 minimum.

DON'T TELL MAMA, 343 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 757-0788. Tonight at 7, Rita Harvey, singer, with Gerry Dieffenbach, pianist; at 8:30, ''The Next Big Broadway Musical,'' musical improvisational comedy; at 9, ''Legendary Ladies,'' female celebrity impersonators. Tomorrow night at 6, Marianne Challis, singer, with Christopher Marlowe, pianist; at 8, Tommy Femia impersonates Judy Garland; at 8:30, ''Poole Party!,'' comedy with Ron Poole; at 11, Steven Brinberg impersonates Barbra Streisand. Sunday at 4 p.m., Sheila Floer, singer, with Richard Atkins, pianist; at 7, Rita Harvey, singer, with Gerry Dieffenbach, pianist. Cover: Free to $18. Two-drink minimum. No credit cards.
FEINSTEIN'S, at the Regency, 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street, (212) 339-4095. The club reopens on Tuesday with Marc Salem. Through Sept. 2.

FIREBIRD CAFE, 363 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 586-0244. Sunday night at 7, Lorraine Feather and Dick Hyman, part of the singer-songwriters series. Cover: $20; $15 minimum. Sunday night at 9, James Beaman, singer-impersonator. Cover: $30; $15 minimum.

HUDSON RIVER PARK'S MOONDANCE SERIES, Pier 25, North Moore Street, near West Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 533-7275. Sunday night, dancing and music begins at 6:30, David Berger and the Sultans of Swing. Free.
JOE'S PUB, Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Tonight at 9, Paulette McWilliams, singer. Tickets: $20.

JUDY'S CHELSEA, 169 Eighth Avenue, at 18th Street, (212) 929-5410. Sunday at 3 p.m., Sarah DeLeo, singer, in ''Going Home,'' with Tracy Stark, pianist. Monday at 10 p.m., ''Leer Mondays,'' with the Lounge-O-Leers, with Ricky Ritzel and Aaron Morishita. Cover: $10 to $20; $10 minimum.

OAK ROOM, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 840-6800. Julie Budd, singer, in ''If You Could See Me Now,'' songs from her new CD. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11:30. Cover: $40, with dinner required for early shows Fridays and Saturdays; $15 food or drink minimum for other shows; suggested dinner arrival for early show is 7. Loston Harris Trio opens Tuesday; through July 29.

SUPPER CLUB, 240 West 47th Street, (212) 921-1940. Tonight and tomorrow night from 8 to midnight, the Supper Club's 17-piece big band. Also, the 25-minute swing revue ''This Joint Is Jumpin' '' on Fridays and Saturdays at 9:30 and 10:30 p.m., with Larry Marshall. Swing dance lessons every Friday and Saturday night from 11:15 to midnight in the Blue Room. Tonight, Jumpin' Gigolos; tomorrow night, Cresent City Mullers, performances from 12:30 to 2:30 a.m. Cover: $25 before 11, $15 after.

TRIAD, 158 West 72nd Street, (212) 362-2590. Tomorrow night at 8, Julia Joseph, singer-songwriter; from midnight, comics from Def Jam, B.E.T, H.B.O. and more. Sunday night at 8, Sean Nowell Jazz Quartet; at 11, Indofunk. Cover: $5 to $15; two-drink minimum.

UPSTAIRS AT ROSE'S TURN, 55 Grove Street, West Village, (212) 366-5438. Tonight at 7, Clare Cooper and Paul Ammendola, singers; at 11, ''Candy Comedy Hour.'' Tomorrow night at 9, Russ Turk, singer; at 11, ''Candy Comedy Hour.'' Sunday night at 10, Adria Malcolm, singer. Cover: $5 to $7; two-drink minimum. No credit cards.
